text:
Wall Street, south side, west from and including Hanover Street, showing the Custom House. This structure was originally the Merchants Exchange. About the turn of the century it became the present National City Bank.

This photo is a duplicate of a print included in this collection.

1886

Gift Thru New York Historical Society

Wall Street, south side, west from and including Hanover Street.
1887-1888.

Ewing Galloway.

First bldg is National City Bank.

82-78 Beaver Street, adjoining and east of the S. E. corner of Hanover Street. At the left is an excavation that extends to Pearl Street, tho the latter is not shown.

July 8, 1903

Wurts Brothers

Beaver Street, north side, east from and across Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co. buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently demolished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros. Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr

Beaver Street, north side, east from and across Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co. buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently demolished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros. Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr

Beaver Street, north side, east from and across Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co. buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently demolished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros. Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr

76-78 and 80 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Hanover Street, as seen across the site of Brown Bros. & Co. Building. Also shown (background), is the Hanover Square Station of the Second and Third Ave. Elevated Line on Pearl Street.

June 10, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Hanover Street, south from Wall to Beaver Streets, showing the building of Brown Bros. & Co. (left foreground). Hanover Street at Exchange Place, makes a bend in an easterly direction, thereby hiding from view, the east side of the street, and exposing the west side.

March 27, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Hanover Street, west side, between Exchange Place (right), and Beaver Street (left), showing the 8-story building of the Canadian Bank of Commerce. It was demolished in 1929, and on its site now stands the 59-story City Bank and Farmer's Trust Company Building. The clearance in the foreground, is at the N.E. corner of Beaver Street, and was created by the demolition of the Brown Bros. and Co. Building. On its site now (1937), stands the 35-story Wall and Hanover Building.
June 30, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Hanover Street, east side; north from Beaver Street to Exchange Place, showing workmen erecting scaffolding for the demolition of the Brown Bros. & Co. Building, which occupies that block. On the left, appears the National City Bank Building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange Place. March 27, 1928. P. L. Sperr.

(2) A part of the same, showing the Brown Bros. Co. Building in an advanced stage of demolition. This site is now (1937) occupied by the 35-story Wall and Hanover Building. June 10, 1928.

(1) Hanover Street, east side; north from Beaver Street to Exchange Place, showing workmen erecting scaffolding for the demolition of the Brown Bros. & Co. Building, which occupies that block. On the left, appears the National City Bank Building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange Place. March 27, 1928. P. L. Sperr.

(2) A part of the same, showing the Brown Bros. Co. Building in an advanced stage of demolition. This site is now (1937) occupied by the 35-story Wall and Hanover Building. June 10, 1928.

(1)
71 Beaver Street at the N.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen across demolition from South William Street. August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a roof on South William Street, showing the continuation of Beaver Street, north side, to Wall Street.

August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
71 Beaver Street at the N.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen across demolition from South William Street. August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a roof on South William Street, showing the continuation of Beaver Street, north side, to Wall Street.

August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

74-70 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen from the N.E. corner of Hanover Street. The view also shows Hanover Street, west side, from and including Beaver to Pearl Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same showing more of No. 70, which is the Coffee Exchange Building.

P. L. Sperr.

September 22, 1929.

(1)

74-70 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen from the N.E. corner of Hanover Street. The view also shows Hanover Street, west side, from and including Beaver to Pearl Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same showing more of No. 70, which is the Coffee Exchange Building.

P. L. Sperr.

September 22, 1929.

Hanover Street, north from Beaver to Wall Streets, showing (right), a portion of the Wall and Hanover Buildings on the N.E. corner. Hanover Street at Exchange Place makes a bend in an easterly direction, thereby hiding from view the east side of the street, and exposing the west side, from Exchange Place to Wall Streets, showing the National City Bank Building, occupying that block. A foot bridge can be seen connecting the latter building, with the 35-story Wall and Hanover Buildings.

June 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Hanover Street, south from Wall Street to Exchange Place, showing (right), a portion of the National City Bank building and (left), a portion of the new Wall and Hanover building. Also shown (under demolition) is the Canadian Bank of Commerce building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange Place and Hanover Street. At the top foreground of the view, is visible part of a foot bridge, connecting the National City Bank with the Wall and Hanover buildings.

September 12 1929

P.L.Sperr

59 Wall Street, (Wall and Hanover Building), Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets. (general view southwestward).

A set of three views from the above location overlooking financial and business structures on Broad Street and Broadway. Across, from left to right these are; the International Telephone Building (flag atop), the Standard Oil Building, the Fred French Building; and the Equitable Trust Co. Building. The last of these is partially obscuring the Columbia Trust Co. Building.

Wall Street is on the right and does not appear. Thru the center of View 2 is Exchange Place. In the background is the North (Hudson) River and the Jersey shore;

View : 1 May 13, 1929
View : 2 and 3 June 26, 1929

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Southwest.

title: General view - Wall Street - Southwest.

text:
59 Wall Street (The Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Building): Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets (general view southeastward).

Shown is Coenties Slip and vicinity as viewed from the above location. Note the "El" making a loop at same after passing down Pearl (foreground) and continuing southward on Front Street. The large structure seen on the left is the Seamens Church Institute, silhouetted against East River piers that extend from South Street.

June 26, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Southeast.

text:
59 Wall Street (The Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Building): Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets (general view southeastward).

Shown is Coenties Slip and vicinity as viewed from the above location. Note the "El" making a loop at same after passing down Pearl (foreground) and continuing southward on Front Street. The large structure seen on the left is the Seamens Church Institute, silhouetted against East River piers that extend from South Street.

June 26, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Southeast.

text:
59 Wall Street, (Wall and Hanover Building); Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets, (general view northwestward).

Two views across Wall Street towards Broadway and City Hall park, showing there the prominent Transportation, Woolworth and Municipal Buildings.

At the left margin is a portion of the National City Building (No. 52 Wall Street) overlooking the elongated Federal Reserve.

June 26, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Northwest.

text:
59 Wall Street, (Wall and Hanover Building); Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets, (general view northwestward).

June 26, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Northwest.

text:
59 Wall Street, (Wall and Hanover Building); Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets, (general view northward).

In the center of View 1 is the Municipal Building. At the left and right margins appear portions of the Federal Reserve and No. 111 John Street buildings. The latter, completed recently, appears to better advantage in View 2. On the opposing side of Pearl Street are the smokestacks and plant of the New York Steam Company.

June 26, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - North.

text:

June 26, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - North.

text:
59 Wall Street (The Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Building): Hanover Street, east side, from Wall to Beaver Streets (general view southeastward).
This triangular area, Coenties Slip, extends eastward from Pearl Street to its base at South Street and has Jeannette Park and the "El" loop therein. The former occupies the easterly portion and the latter the apex. To the left is the East River merging into the Upper Bay at Governor's Island which appears in the distance.

August 28, 1929
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Southeast.

text:

title: General view - Wall Street - Southeast.

text:
Beaver Street, east from William across Hanover to Pearl Streets, showing the lower portions of the skyscrapers that fill this, the financial district; that on the left is the City Bank, Farmers Trust Company, and on the right, the New York Cotton Exchange.

November 7, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
